I won't say they were black because the Greeks who studied in Egypt never used the word black. The word used was “Melanchroes”. That's how Herodotus, Diodorus, Strabo and other greek historians described the ancient Egyptians. Many scholars argue that the Egyptians were not black because the Greeks used a different word to describe Sudanese people. The word was “Aethiopes” meaning “of the burnt face”. So the word Melanchroe only suggests that the Egyptians were a people of color. Likely dark skinned but not as black as their southern relatives who were Cushites. Today there are many Hamitic people in India, South America, and even the horn of Africa who are dark skinned but not necessarily black. According to the Bible, Ham was the father of Cush (meaning “black”. He fathered the Ethiopians/Sudanese people) The second son of Ham was the brother of Cush. His name was Mizraim meaning “two lands” or “double straits”. He was the father of the Egyptians, Philistines and other North African peoples. He had a son called “Lybsos”. The Jewish historian Josephus flavius said that the name of this son was later given to the land we call Libya. The next son was Phut and the last was cursed with slavery. His name was Canaan. Ham is “Chamam” in Arabic and “Kham” in hebrew. It is the root word of the ancient name of Egypt (“Khemet”) and Cush was called “Kerma”. The word Khem in Egyptian means “black”. In hebrew the word Ham/ Kham means “hot”. In Arabic the word Ham/Chamam means “to be burnt” or “to be black". So we can be at least sure that the Egyptians were swarthy by nature with or without exposure to sunlight. But their degree of swarthyness can only be determined by melanin testing on Mummies. I read UNESCO “General history of Africa” and Diop conducted melanin dosage tests on Mummies in France. His conclusion was that they were black. That is not definite since we know that Egyptians were related to cushites and absorbed them into the state. There was always a heavy cushite presence in Egypt. It would have been conclusive with further testing, but at the Cairo symposium, Egyptian authorities did not allow any melanin dosage tests to be conducted on other mummies. My Final take: Jer 13:23 “Can the Cushite change the color of his skin”? If the Egyptians were black, why was the Cushite singled out in this verse. Why were Moses and Paul mistaken for Egyptians? The blackness of Egypt can only be resolved if we acknowledge the deep cultural, ethnic and historical interconnectedness between the Egyptians and their Cushite relatives. They fought battles together. They defended cities like Thebes together. And in the Bible, they were almost always mentioned together in prophecy after prophecy. This debate lives on because we have not yet reached a consensus as to how we should define blackness. Western view: Blacks are any group of people related to the the victims of the transatlantic traffic or who share their broader phenotype i.e Wooly hair, broad nose, thick lips, enlarge buttocks e.t.c Objective view: Blacks are people who have a black skin color regardless of their facial features, or the lands to which they are indigenous.
